sn42.12:1.1: Nothing further is known of this chief. His name means “heaper”, perhaps in reference to the wealth that is heaped up and the suffering that is worn away.
sn42.12:2.1: The Buddha repeats the opening of the First Sermon (SN 56.11). The text goes on to illustrate these two extremes and the middle way. The lengthy explanation suggests that Rāsiya was slow of understanding.
sn42.12:3.1: This is the first extreme, sensual indulgence. A similar analysis is at AN 10.91.
sn42.12:16.1: This is the second extreme, self mortification.
sn42.12:16.4: In Buddhism, a “skillful quality” would refer to the “ten ways of doing skillful deeds”, which are good qualities for a human life lived well. Beyond that are the “superhuman” states realized by advanced meditators, namely absorptions, psychic powers, and stages of awakening (Bu Pj 4:4.1.3.1).
sn42.12:22.1: The middle way is described as a “wearing away” (nijjara). The Jains believed that through the practice of austerities one could “wear away” past bad deeds (MN 14:17.5) and future suffering (MN 14:17.8). The Buddha distinguishes the term from self-mortification and adapts it for Buddhist use, with “wearing away” applied to the defilements that produce suffering. It is applied to the tenfold path at AN 10.106.
